required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Uterocervical Angle: a Screening Tool That Estimates the Latent Phase Duration in Post Term Pregnancies
clinical_study.official_title: Anterior Uterocervical Angle for Latent Phase Duration in Post Term Pregnancies

lead_sponsor.agency: Sanliurfa Mehmet Akif Inan Education and Research Hospital

clinical_study.source: Sanliurfa Mehmet Akif Inan Education and Research Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: To evaluate the performance of uterocervical angle (UCA) in the prediction of latent phase duration in post term pregnancies

primary_outcome.measure: prediction of latent phase duration by uterocervical angle in post term pregnancies
primary_outcome.description: In patients diagnosed with late term pregnancy, the uterocervical angle and cervical length were measured by transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) at the time of admission to the delivery room before labor induction.

secondary_outcome.measure: the relative success of UCA in active phase and duration of labor prediction in post term pregnancies

arm_group.description: uterocervical angle is the angle between lower segment of uterus and cervix

intervention.description: latent phase duration in post term pregnancies
uterocervical angle is the angle between lower segment of uterus and cervix

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with singleton pregnancies
- Post term pregnancies
- Patients with vertex presentation,
- Patients with intact membranes
- Patients with no uterine contractions
Exclusion Criteria:
- women with BMI >30,
- multiparity and multiple pregnancies,
- patients with macrosomia (>4500 gr),
- patients with major fetal congenital abnormality or fetal death and any contraindications to vaginal birth (e.g. active genital herpes),
- patients with abnormal Pap smears,
- patients with a history of previous cesarean section, myomectomy, hysteroscopic surgeries, dilatation and curettages, loop electrosurgical excision procedures, and cervical conization.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Sanliurfa Mehmet Akif Inan Education and Research Hospital
responsible_party.investigator_title: Ph.D. Assistant Professor Department of Obstetrics and Gynecolog
